medium: Mineral colors and gold on sized cotton
title: Thanka of Yonten Gyalpo
text:
Yonten Gyalpo is a dharmapala or "protector of the religion". He is one of the five Great Kings, the Gyalpo Kunga who are protectors of the Tibetan government and of Buddhism.

This exquisitely painted dark ground thanka shows a red Yonten Gyalpo on the center wearing a cane hat and riding a black horse. In his outstretched right hand he holds a vajra, in his left hand a skull cup. Three monks are in clouds above his head indicating that the thanka belongs to the Gelugpa tradition. Beneath Yonten Gyalpo are other protective deities and members of the Tibetan pantheon astride various animals including the mythical Chi-lin, horse, elephant, white lion, and tiger. All the figures are set against green and blue cloud scrolls or flame designs, carefully outlined in gold. The brushwork of this small painting is exceptionally well rendered with fine detail and precise gold work. Its condition with original silk mounts and well-preserved surface is also remarkable.
description: figure with red skin wearing a gold hat, riding on a black horse; 4 figures floating on clouds at top; 8 small figures on horseback and riding other animals at bottom; green silk cover
creditline: Gift of Ruth and Bruce Dayton
